docs.lead_paragraph: THOUGH we all know that you cannot judge a book by its cover, when it comes to judging other people, most of us do just that. We say that people look young, look happy, look tired, look intelligent, and we are often content to be deceived by appearances. This tendency, combined with an intense societal emphasis on youth and beauty, has made the face lift one of the most sought elective operations in the nation. No longer the exclusive province of the rich and the famous, face lifts are undergone by women and an increasing number of men from all walks of life: the recently divorced who want to attract new mates, career men and women who want to hold their own against younger competition, ordinary folks who do not want to look older than they feel. Each year about half a million Americans choose to turn back the clock by surgically erasing obvious ravages of age on their faces. But too often, under the subtle pressure of publicity and wishful thinking, people go into face-lift operations unprepared for what they entail, what they can and cannot accomplish and what risks they may involve.
